title: KEEN Women's Targhee III Review: The Ultimate Hiking Boot Guide for 2025
description: Complete review of KEEN Women's Targhee III hiking boots. Expert analysis, user reviews, sizing guide, and performance insights for serious hikers in 2025.

body:
KEEN Women's Targhee III Review: The Ultimate Hiking Boot Guide for 2025

After spending countless hours on mountain trails across the Pacific Northwest, I've tested dozens of hiking boots. The KEEN Women's Targhee III has consistently proven itself as a reliable companion for serious hikers. This comprehensive review covers everything you need to know about these iconic boots, from their waterproof performance to sizing considerations. Whether you're planning weekend day hikes or multi-day backpacking adventures, this guide will help you make an informed decision. For more outdoor gear reviews, visit our homepage.

Table of Contents

  • 1. Overview and First Impressions
  • 2. Key Features and Technology
  • 3. Trail Performance Analysis
  • 4. Sizing and Fit Guide
  • 5. My Real-World Experience
  • 6. Comparisons and User Reviews
  • 7. Conclusion

Overview and First Impressions

The KEEN Women's Targhee III represents the evolution of one of hiking's most trusted boot lines. Having personally tested these boots across diverse terrains from Olympic National Park's rainforests to the dry trails of Zion, I can confidently say they've earned their reputation as a hiker's reliable companion.

What immediately strikes you about the KEEN Women's Targhee III is the substantial feel without excessive bulk. Unlike the chunkier Targhee II, this third iteration strikes a better balance between protection and agility. The leather upper feels premium yet supple, while the signature KEEN toe bumper provides that extra protection we've all come to appreciate when scrambling over rocky terrain.

Quick Specs

  • Weight: 2 lbs (size 8.5)
  • Waterproofing: KEEN.DRY technology
  • Upper: Waterproof leather and performance mesh
  • Outsole: KEEN.RUGGED with 4mm lugs
  • Available Widths: Regular and Wide

The boot's construction speaks to KEEN's commitment to durability. After hundreds of miles on various trails, from the muddy paths of the Hoh River Trail to the loose scree of Mount Rainier's Tolmie Peak, these boots have maintained their structural integrity remarkably well. The stitching remains tight, the leather shows minimal scuffing, and most importantly, the waterproofing continues to perform flawlessly.

Check Current Price on Amazon

Key Features and Technology

KEEN.DRY Waterproof Technology

The cornerstone of the KEEN Women's Targhee III is its waterproof-breathable membrane. KEEN's proprietary KEEN.DRY technology creates an effective barrier against moisture while allowing perspiration to escape. During my creek crossings in the Cascade Range, where I've deliberately submerged these boots in icy mountain streams, my feet remained completely dry.

What sets KEEN.DRY apart from competitors is its integration with the boot's overall construction. The membrane doesn't feel like an afterthought – it's seamlessly woven into the boot's architecture, maintaining breathability even during strenuous summer hikes. I've worn these boots during 10-hour hiking days in 85-degree weather, and while my feet worked up a sweat, they never felt uncomfortably damp or clammy.

Superior Traction System

The KEEN.RUGGED outsole with its 4mm multi-directional lugs provides exceptional grip across diverse terrain types. From the slick wooden boardwalks of Olympic's temperate rainforest to the granite slabs of Yosemite's approach trails, I've consistently felt confident in my footing. The lug pattern features a strategic combination of deep channels for mud clearance and varied angles for optimal bite on different surfaces.

Pro Tip: The outsole compound performs exceptionally well in temperatures ranging from 20°F to 90°F. I've found it maintains flexibility and grip even during early season hikes when morning frost transitions to afternoon heat.

Roomy Toe Box Design

One of the most celebrated features of the KEEN Women's Targhee III is its generous toe box. KEEN's "Original Fit" philosophy provides ample space for natural toe splay, which becomes crucial during long descents when feet naturally swell. This design particularly benefits hikers with wider feet or those who experience foot swelling during extended activities.

The spacious forefoot doesn't compromise the boot's performance. The speed-lace webbing system allows for precise adjustment, ensuring the midfoot and heel remain securely locked while giving toes freedom to move naturally. This balance prevents the sloppy feel that sometimes accompanies overly roomy boots while eliminating the pinched sensation of narrow designs.

View Low-Cut Version

Trail Performance Analysis

Weight and Comfort Balance

At 2 pounds for a women's size 8.5, the KEEN Women's Targhee III sits in the moderate weight category for hiking boots. While not ultralight, this weight contributes directly to the boot's durability and protection. During my 15-mile day hike on the Enchantment Lakes Trail, the boots felt substantial enough to handle rocky terrain without becoming burdensome during the long approach.

The comfort factor extends beyond mere weight considerations. The foam midsole provides adequate cushioning for day hikes while maintaining enough firmness for stability under a loaded backpack. I've carried packs up to 35 pounds while wearing these boots, and the sole's support never felt inadequate, even during steep descents where impact forces multiply.

Seasonal Performance

Through three seasons of testing (I don't recommend them for serious winter conditions), the KEEN Women's Targhee III has proven remarkably versatile. Spring hikes through snowmelt and muddy conditions showcase the waterproofing, while summer's heat tests the breathability. Fall hiking in the Cascades, with its mix of wet leaves and early frost, represents perhaps the ideal conditions for these boots.

Strengths

  • Excellent waterproof performance
  • Durable leather construction
  • Superior traction on varied terrain
  • Comfortable for wide feet
  • Good ankle support

Considerations

  • Heavier than ultralight alternatives
  • Break-in period required
  • Limited breathability in hot weather
  • Sizing can run slightly large

Temperature regulation deserves special mention. While the boots handle cool and moderate temperatures excellently, hot summer days (above 85°F) can challenge the system. However, this limitation is common among waterproof boots, and the KEEN Women's Targhee III performs better than many competitors in this regard.

For those interested in different variations, I recommend exploring the waterproof collection or considering the mid-height version for additional ankle support.

Sizing and Fit Guide

True-to-Size Performance

Based on extensive testing and feedback from fellow hikers, the KEEN Women's Targhee III runs true to size for most feet. However, KEEN's generous toe box means the boots may feel slightly roomier than other brands' equivalent sizes. I typically wear a size 8.5 in athletic shoes and find the same size perfect in these boots, providing adequate toe space without excess volume.

The critical consideration is sock thickness and intended use. For day hiking with standard hiking socks, your regular size should work perfectly. If you plan on winter hiking with thick wool socks or have feet that swell significantly during long hikes, consider going up half a size. The wide width option provides additional accommodation for broader feet.

Sizing Recommendations

Narrow to Average Feet:

Order your normal athletic shoe size. The roomy toe box will provide comfortable space without feeling loose.

Wide Feet:

Start with regular width in your normal size. If needed, the wide width option offers additional room.

Break-in Period

Unlike many hiking boots that require extensive break-in periods, the KEEN Women's Targhee III offers remarkable out-of-the-box comfort. The supple leather upper and well-designed interior minimize hot spots and pressure points during initial wear. I experienced only minor heel adjustment during the first 10-15 miles, primarily due to the boot conforming to my foot's specific shape.

For optimal break-in, I recommend starting with shorter day hikes (3-5 miles) before committing to longer adventures. The speed-lace system allows for fine-tuning throughout the day as your feet adjust to the boot's characteristics. Pay particular attention to the lacing tension across the instep – too tight can create pressure points, while too loose compromises support.

Those considering different height options might explore the low-cut version for enhanced mobility or the waterproof mid-height for additional protection.

Compare with Targhee II

My Real-World Experience

Over 18 months and approximately 400 trail miles, my relationship with the KEEN Women's Targhee III has evolved from cautious optimism to genuine trust. These boots have accompanied me through some of the Pacific Northwest's most challenging terrain, from the muddy bottomlands of the Hoh River to the exposed ridgelines of Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest.

Memorable Trail Tests

The most demanding test came during a three-day backpacking trip on the Enchantment Lakes Trail in early October. Day one presented perfect conditions – dry trail, moderate temperatures, and stunning alpine scenery. The KEEN Women's Targhee III performed flawlessly, providing stable footing during the steep approach and comfortable support during long flat sections.

Day two brought unexpected weather: overnight snow followed by morning rain, creating a treacherous mix of slush and mud. This is where the boots truly shined. The KEEN.DRY technology kept my feet completely dry through creek crossings and slushy sections, while the aggressive tread pattern provided confidence-inspiring traction on slippery granite.

Trail Wisdom: A ranger at North Cascades National Park mentioned that KEEN boots are among the most commonly seen on demanding trails, praising their durability and the company's commitment to repairability. This real-world endorsement from someone who sees hundreds of hikers weekly carries significant weight.

Seasonal Performance Notes

Spring hiking in the Cascades tests waterproof capabilities like no other season. Snowmelt creates miniature rivers across trails, while residual snow patches hide deceptively deep puddles. During a Memorial Day weekend hike on the Blue Lake Trail, I deliberately stepped through every water hazard I encountered. After eight hours of intentionally abusive treatment, my feet remained dry and comfortable.

Summer's heat presents different challenges. While hiking Mount Pilchuck in 82-degree weather, I appreciated the boots' breathability more than expected. Yes, my feet were warm, but they weren't uncomfortably hot or swampy. The key is proper sock selection – merino wool wicks moisture effectively even in warm conditions.

Fall hiking showcases these boots at their absolute best. Cool mornings, variable conditions, and mixed terrain play directly to their strengths. The KEEN Women's Targhee III handles wet leaves, morning frost, and rocky scrambles with equal competence. For those seeking similar performance in different styles, the complete women's collection offers various options.

See Latest Targhee IV

Comparisons and User Reviews

Real User Experiences

Sarah M. - Amazon Reviewer (5/5 Stars)

"I have wide feet and high arches, making boot shopping a nightmare. The KEEN Women's Targhee III fit perfectly out of the box. After 6 months of regular hiking, they still look and feel great. The waterproofing is legit – I've walked through streams and my feet stayed bone dry. Highly recommend for anyone with fit issues."

Trail_Runner_Jenny - Reddit User

"Loved these boots initially, but after about 200 miles, the heel area started wearing more than expected. Still waterproof and comfortable, but durability isn't quite what I hoped for the price point. Good for day hikes, but I'd choose something else for serious backpacking."

MountainMama_2019 - Quora Contributor

"As someone who hikes 2-3 times per week, I need boots that can handle frequent use. The KEEN Women's Targhee III has exceeded expectations. Great traction, true waterproofing, and the comfort level makes long days enjoyable. The toe box is spacious without being sloppy. Would definitely buy again."

Competitive Landscape

When compared to the Merrell Moab 3, the KEEN Women's Targhee III offers superior waterproofing and durability at the cost of some weight. The Moab edges ahead in breathability but can't match KEEN's toe protection and overall ruggedness. For hikers prioritizing long-term reliability over ultralight performance, the Targhee III represents better value.

Against Salomon's X Ultra 3 GTX, the comparison becomes more complex. Salomon offers a more athletic feel and lighter weight, while KEEN provides better accommodation for wider feet and superior protection. The choice often comes down to foot shape and hiking style – technical hikers might prefer Salomon's precision, while traditional hikers appreciate KEEN's comfort-first approach.

Expert Recommendation

The KEEN Women's Targhee III excels as an all-around hiking boot for moderate to challenging day hikes and weekend backpacking. While not the lightest option available, its combination of waterproofing, durability, and comfort makes it ideal for hikers who prioritize reliability over cutting-edge performance metrics.

For those exploring the broader KEEN ecosystem, consider the waterproof hiking shoe version for lighter adventures or the complete Targhee III lineup for different height and feature combinations.

Explore KEEN Pyrenees Alternative

Conclusion

After extensive real-world testing, the KEEN Women's Targhee III earns a strong recommendation for hikers seeking a reliable, comfortable, and durable boot for moderate to challenging trail conditions. These boots represent KEEN's commitment to practical design over flashy features, resulting in footwear that simply works consistently across diverse conditions.

The combination of proven KEEN.DRY waterproofing, generous toe box accommodation, and robust construction makes these boots particularly suitable for hikers with wider feet or those who prioritize comfort during long trail days. While not the lightest option in their category, the KEEN Women's Targhee III provides peace of mind through reliable performance and build quality.

Final Verdict

Rating: 4.2/5 Stars

Best For:

  • Day hiking and weekend backpacking
  • Hikers with wide feet
  • Wet and variable conditions
  • Moderate to challenging terrain

Consider Alternatives If:

  • Weight is your primary concern
  • You have narrow feet
  • You prioritize maximum breathability
  • Budget is extremely tight

For those ready to invest in reliable hiking footwear, the KEEN Women's Targhee III represents solid value in the mid-to-upper price range. The boots' proven track record, backed by KEEN's reputation for customer service and quality, makes them a sensible choice for serious hikers who plan to log significant trail miles.

Whether you're planning weekend adventures in your local mountains or considering more ambitious multi-day treks, these boots provide the foundation for confident, comfortable hiking. The investment in quality footwear pays dividends in terms of foot health, hiking enjoyment, and long-term durability. For additional options within the KEEN family, explore the complete Targhee III collection.

Get Your KEEN Women's Targhee III Today

Frequently Asked Questions

Are KEEN Women's Targhee III boots true to size?

Yes, the KEEN Women's Targhee III generally runs true to size, though the generous toe box may feel roomier than other brands. Most hikers find their regular athletic shoe size works perfectly. However, if you have narrow feet or prefer a snugger fit, you might consider going down half a size. For wide feet, the regular size typically provides excellent accommodation, with a wide width option available if needed. I recommend trying them on with your preferred hiking socks to ensure optimal fit before committing to longer hikes.

How waterproof are the KEEN Women's Targhee III boots?

The waterproof performance of the KEEN Women's Targhee III is excellent, utilizing KEEN.DRY technology that creates a reliable barrier against moisture. In my testing, including deliberate stream crossings and prolonged exposure to wet conditions, the boots kept feet completely dry. The waterproof membrane is durable and maintains effectiveness even after hundreds of miles of use. However, like all waterproof boots, they're less breathable than non-waterproof alternatives, which can lead to moisture buildup during intense summer hiking. The waterproofing works best in cool to moderate temperatures where breathability isn't as critical.

What's the difference between Targhee II and Targhee III?

The Targhee III represents a refined evolution of the Targhee II design. Key improvements include a sleeker profile that reduces bulk while maintaining protection, updated materials for better durability, and enhanced traction patterns on the outsole. The Targhee III feels more like a hiking shoe than a traditional boot compared to its predecessor, with a slightly lower heel differential and improved flexibility. The toe box remains generously sized in both versions, but the III offers better overall comfort and a more contemporary aesthetic. Performance-wise, the III provides similar waterproofing and protection with improved agility on technical terrain.

How long do KEEN Targhee III boots typically last?

With proper care and moderate use, the KEEN Women's Targhee III can last 300-500 miles of hiking, depending on terrain and hiking style. The durable leather upper and robust construction contribute to longevity, while the KEEN.RUGGED outsole maintains traction even as it wears. Factors affecting lifespan include frequency of use, terrain type, and maintenance practices. Regular cleaning, proper drying between uses, and occasional waterproofing treatment can extend boot life significantly. Many users report getting 12-24 months of regular hiking use from a single pair. The replaceable footbed allows for extended comfort even as the boot ages, making them a good long-term investment for serious hikers.

Are these boots suitable for winter hiking?

The KEEN Women's Targhee III works well for light winter conditions and three-season hiking, but isn't designed for serious winter mountaineering. They provide excellent waterproofing and decent insulation for temperatures down to around 20°F with appropriate socks. The traction is adequate for light snow and ice, but not sufficient for technical winter conditions requiring crampons. For winter day hiking on maintained trails with minimal snow, they perform admirably. However, for serious winter backpacking or mountaineering, consider dedicated winter boots with enhanced insulation and more aggressive traction systems. The boots excel in spring and fall conditions where temperatures fluctuate around freezing.
